ingredients:
Ingredients:

  • '00' flour (300g)
  • 2 eggs and 4 yolks, lightly beaten
  • Extra flour for dusting
recipe1: Combine the flour and the egg mix with a pinch of salt.  Work the mix either by hand or in a food mixer until it forms large crumbs; if the dough feels a little dry at this stage add a little water, 1 tsp at a time.
recipe2: Tip the dough onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth, about a minute or so. Cover with cling film and leave to rest for 30 minutes.
recipe3: If you're using a pasta machine feed it through on the  widest setting, then fold into three, give the dough a quarter turn and feed through the pasta machine again.  Repeat this process once more then continue to pass the dough through the machine, progressively narrowing the rollers, one notch at a time, until you have a smooth sheet of pasta.  On the narrowest setting, feed the sheet through twice.
recipe4: If you're rolling by hand follow roll the dough out as thinly as possible then follow the same process of folding in three, turning by a quarter, then rolling again.  It's a lot of work!
recipe5: Cut as required for the dish, either into neat sheets for lasagne, or into lengths for spaghetti, linguine, tagliatelle.  Then dust in flour (semolina if available, or a little more of the durum) and set aside until ready to use.
aside1:
Did you know....

Traditionally, ‘00’ flour is used for egg pasta as it’s high in gluten.

The gluten stops the pasta from snapping when rolling out or cutting into strands.

You can also make pasta with plain or plain strong flour, but it will be harder to work with.
